commit_message:
py3: port the test of locale

We needed to change the sample translation a little, because
Python 3 requires encoding metadata.

We also remove workarounds for a specific bug in the subprocess
module, which were needed on Python 2.6 only.

Change-Id: Ie7791297cab16a649880088fa9eae6b4f95855f7

subject: Build bootstrap_nodeid var from primary_role_name
messages: [{'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2019-06-20 18:41:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2019-06-20 19:04:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2019-06-20 19:06:33.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned\n\nthis was fixed in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/605728/ and not backported to Queens.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-20 18:41:53.000000000', 'message': "Build bootstrap_nodeid var from primary_role_name

We can only have one single bootstrap_nodeid per deployment, and if we
have more we will have multiple nodes running some tasks that are
supposed to run from only one node, like DB syncs or cluster initiation.

To prevent that, we can use the primary_role_name variable which is the
name of role which has both 'controller' & 'primary' tags in it.

Before that, we were building bootstrap_nodeid by using the first node
in the role; which can be problematic if for example we have multiple
roles for 'controller' tags.

Change-Id: I6a6dd97d08e1502842473d07a05e01148156834e
Related-Bug: #1822327
"}]
commit_message:
Build bootstrap_nodeid var from primary_role_name

We can only have one single bootstrap_nodeid per deployment, and if we
have more we will have multiple nodes running some tasks that are
supposed to run from only one node, like DB syncs or cluster initiation.

To prevent that, we can use the primary_role_name variable which is the
name of role which has both 'controller' & 'primary' tags in it.

Before that, we were building bootstrap_nodeid by using the first node
in the role; which can be problematic if for example we have multiple
roles for 'controller' tags.

Change-Id: I6a6dd97d08e1502842473d07a05e01148156834e
Related-Bug: #1822327

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-25 15:58:32.000000000', 'message': "Raise InstanceFaultRollback for UnableToMigrateToSelf from _prep_resize

It is possible to cold migrate a stopped server. If, however, the
cold migrate is scheduled to the instance's current host and the
compute driver does not support cold migrating to the same host,
then UnableToMigrateToSelf was being raised from _prep_resize. If
_reschedule_resize_or_reraise re-raises that exception, then
_error_out_instance_on_exception in prep_resize handles it and
sets the instance vm_state to ACTIVE. This is wrong since the
instance power state is unchanged at this point and the instance
is actually stopped.

This fixes the problem by wrapping UnableToMigrateToSelf in
InstanceFaultRollback and raises that from _prep_resize, and
_error_out_instance_on_exception is called with the initial
vm_state (STOPPED in this case) so when _error_out_instance_on_exception
handles the InstanceFaultRollback exception it sets the instance
vm_state to STOPPED (what it already was) rather than ACTIVE.

There were no existing unit tests for the UnableToMigrateToSelf
case in _prep_resize so those are added here.

Change-Id: I17543ecb572934ecc7d0bbc7a4ad2f537fa499bc
Closes-Bug: #1811235
"}, {'created': '2019-01-25 16:00:15.000000000', 'message': "Raise InstanceFaultRollback for UnableToMigrateToSelf from _prep_resize

Change-Id: I17543ecb572934ecc7d0bbc7a4ad2f537fa499bc

_reschedule_resize_or_reraise re-raises that exception, then
_error_out_instance_on_exception in prep_resize handles it and
sets the instance vm_state to ACTIVE. This is wrong since the
instance power state is unchanged at this point and the instance
is actually stopped.

This fixes the problem by wrapping UnableToMigrateToSelf in
InstanceFaultRollback and raises that from _prep_resize, and
_error_out_instance_on_exception is called with the initial
vm_state (STOPPED in this case) so when _error_out_instance_on_exception
handles the InstanceFaultRollback exception it sets the instance
vm_state to STOPPED (what it already was) rather than ACTIVE.

There were no existing unit tests for the UnableToMigrateToSelf
case in _prep_resize so those are added here.

Change-Id: I17543ecb572934ecc7d0bbc7a4ad2f537fa499bc
Closes-Bug: #1811235

commit_message:
Raise InstanceFaultRollback for UnableToMigrateToSelf from _prep_resize

It is possible to cold migrate a stopped server. If, however, the
cold migrate is scheduled to the instance's current host and the
compute driver does not support cold migrating to the same host,
then UnableToMigrateToSelf was being raised from _prep_resize. If
_reschedule_resize_or_reraise re-raises that exception, then
_error_out_instance_on_exception in prep_resize handles it and
sets the instance vm_state to ACTIVE. This is wrong since the
instance power state is unchanged at this point and the instance
is actually stopped.

This fixes the problem by wrapping UnableToMigrateToSelf in
InstanceFaultRollback and raises that from _prep_resize, and
_error_out_instance_on_exception is called with the initial
vm_state (STOPPED in this case) so when _error_out_instance_on_exception
handles the InstanceFaultRollback exception it sets the instance
vm_state to STOPPED (what it already was) rather than ACTIVE.

There were no existing unit tests for the UnableToMigrateToSelf
case in _prep_resize so those are added here.

Change-Id: I17543ecb572934ecc7d0bbc7a4ad2f537fa499bc
Closes-Bug: #1811235

I am not sure if I get your point. But according to this line https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/compute/api.py#L3493, request_spec will load data from api db, and should contain pci_requests if it was supplied to the original create request.'}, {'account_id': 7543, 'date': '2018-08-06 02:00:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@chen, it did not load if you not explicitly specified. pci_requests is one of lazy attribute of the instance.  refer to nova/objects/instance.py: _from_db_object.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-08-08 00:19:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Agree with Chen. If the issue is that the instance is really old and doesn't have a request spec, so we have to build a request spec from the instance, then please explain that and why lazy-loading the instance.pci_requests to create the request spec in conductor (before we call the scheduler) does not work. The commit message doesn't explain the bug otherwise. Also, which release are you hitting this on? Maybe it's fixed on a newer version that you're not using?"}, {'account_id': 7543, 'date': '2018-08-08 02:24:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

maybe here is the problem:
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/681cb7f21f2ecab7b6c0451b746ab6f45c5a515c/nova/api/openstack/compute/migrate_server.py#L53

way before the call to the compute node's command, the migrate API create a instance from compute_api.get, which is not the logic you guys talk about.

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/681cb7f21f2ecab7b6c0451b746ab6f45c5a515c/nova/compute/api.py#L2388"}, {'account_id': 7543, 'date': '2018-08-08 02:45:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

i use master."}, {'account_id': 27738, 'date': '2018-08-08 04:05:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

vmware-recheck-patch'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-08-08 13:03:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> maybe here is the problem: https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/681cb7f21f2ecab7b6c0451b746ab6f45c5a515c/nova/api/openstack/compute/migrate_server.py#L53

No I don't think so. As noted (several times), the scheduler uses the RequestSpec, it doesn't care about the instance, so what matters is getting the RequestSpec, which should exist for the instance and should have the pci_requests in it."}, {'account_id': 7543, 'date': '2018-08-09 02:02:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

thanks Matt.
i got you idea.  i did verify the problem on master, then, seems this fix is suspicious, i need dig into that to figure out why.'}, {'account_id': 7543, 'date': '2018-08-09 08:10:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I confirmed the request_spec always rebuild on conductor(by adding debug message) from component which use instance.pci_request as parameter:
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/fc25d8a93cb91f348bb4fc1c4fa471a03c62e730/nova/conductor/manager.py#L304

the conductor won't rebuild the instance object anyway, this indicate the request_spec been deleted on rpcAPI:
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/fc25d8a93cb91f348bb4fc1c4fa471a03c62e730/nova/conductor/rpcapi.py#L325

the reason it running here might because(not confirmed yet) the RPC client's version is fixed at v1.0 (while init the RPC client):
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/fc25d8a93cb91f348bb4fc1c4fa471a03c62e730/nova/conductor/rpcapi.py#L290


so, i gonna confirmed the last thing, and update another version's fix. 

the request_spec on conductor might need load from db like we first time boot the instance."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-08-09 17:03:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

The reason the request_spec isn't available from compute to conductor during a reschedule for a resize is because compute doesn't send it back to conductor on reschedule, see:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/582417/

So we should call RequestSpec.from_primitives which uses instance.pci_requests which should get lazy-loaded. If that's not happening, we need to understand why."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-08-09 17:05:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Sorry, meant "RequestSpec.from_components".'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-08-09 17:11:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-06-20 18:48:42.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

No updates on the review in a long time so I'm going to abandon this."}]

commit_message:
Load expected attr pci_devices while migrate

Load 'pci_requests' explicitly otherwise the request_spec missed it,
NUMATopologyFilter and PciPassthroughFilter then return True for any
hosts.

Change-Id: Ie95f18a6d0e46771410659e34dc8a6f35e149729
Closes-Bug: #1782696

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-25 14:05:23.000000000', 'message': 'Change InstanceFaultRollback handling in _error_out_instance_on_exception

For some reason, only NotImplementedError in _error_out_instance_on_exception
would use the $instance_state parameter which can be controller by the
caller of the context manager to determine the rollback vm_state. But in the
case of InstanceFaultRollback, the caller may want to reset the vm_state
back to something other than ACTIVE, like if the instance is actually
STOPPED and somehting like prep_resize fails (you can resize a STOPPED
instance).

This change makes _error_out_instance_on_exception handle InstanceFaultRollback
like NotImplementedError in that the instance_state parameter is used to reset
the instance.vm_state. It also adds a docstring explaining how this context
manager works along with some notes/questions about ways to improve it.

Change-Id: Ie4f9177f4d54cbc7dbcf58bd107fd5f24c60d8bb
Related-Bug: #1811235

like NotImplementedError in that the instance_state parameter is used to reset
the instance.vm_state. It also adds a docstring explaining how this context
manager works along with some notes/questions about ways to improve it.

Change-Id: Ie4f9177f4d54cbc7dbcf58bd107fd5f24c60d8bb
Related-Bug: #1811235

For some reason, only NotImplementedError in _error_out_instance_on_exception
would use the $instance_state parameter which can be controlled by the
caller of the context manager to determine the rollback vm_state. But in the

commit_message:
Change InstanceFaultRollback handling in _error_out_instance_on_exception

For some reason, only NotImplementedError in _error_out_instance_on_exception
would use the $instance_state parameter which can be controlled by the
caller of the context manager to determine the rollback vm_state. But in the
case of InstanceFaultRollback, the caller may want to reset the vm_state
back to something other than ACTIVE, like if the instance is actually
STOPPED and something like prep_resize fails (you can resize a STOPPED
instance).

This change makes _error_out_instance_on_exception handle InstanceFaultRollback
like NotImplementedError in that the instance_state parameter is used to reset
the instance.vm_state. It also adds a docstring explaining how this context
manager works along with some notes/questions about ways to improve it.

Change-Id: Ie4f9177f4d54cbc7dbcf58bd107fd5f24c60d8bb
Related-Bug: #1811235

commit_message:
Enable Ceph RGW 'account in url' option

This requires an update of the endpoint but is necessary to be able
to use public-readable containers (like temporary URLs) with RGW.

Change-Id: I6bd11bdf9c74db24c0d21fa600030e9f3b144df0
Closes-Bug: 1826894

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-10 17:06:00.000000000', 'message': 'Change new image property to hw_mem_encryption

The AMD SEV spec currently proposes to add a "hw:mem_encryption"
parameter to flavor extra specs and image properties.  However
existing extra specs parameters use the "hw:" prefix, whereas image
properties all use the "hw_" prefix.

Therefore to remain consistent with those conventions, change the
proposal so that the new image property will be called
"hw_mem_encryption" rather than "hw:mem_encryption".

Change-Id: Id119dbf40585556c4063ba64aed11347b5979138
'}]
commit_message:
Change new image property to hw_mem_encryption

The AMD SEV spec currently proposes to add a "hw:mem_encryption"
parameter to flavor extra specs and image properties.  However
existing extra specs parameters use the "hw:" prefix, whereas image
properties all use the "hw_" prefix.

Therefore to remain consistent with those conventions, change the
proposal so that the new image property will be called
"hw_mem_encryption" rather than "hw:mem_encryption".

Change-Id: Id119dbf40585556c4063ba64aed11347b5979138

commit_message:
Import the tripleo-create-admin role

This change adds the "tripleo-create-admin" role from tripleo-common.
This change creates all of the molecule tests required to ensure that
the role is properly exercised using all of it's documented code
paths.

Documentation hooks have been added showing how the role can be
used.

Change-Id: I5649e5af6b18c411d7bbbe230556c04aeddf2795
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Override ovn::controller::hostname to use hiera:fqdn_canonical

ovn::controller::hostname defaults to ::fqdn,
hostname can differ based on how nova configures it, detected
when dhcp_domain name is removed in [1].
So it's good to rely on fqdn_canonical hiera key which
nova also relies on to set "host" in nova.conf.

This backport excludes neutron_url_timeout chnage.

Related-Bug: #1829993
Change-Id: If52302b5a04b5e146ac53ccd3fc65a064b2df2fb
(cherry picked from commit 5e83eeda5b5d85022a48b71c10bcad0155063779)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-19 17:02:30.000000000', 'message': "RabbitMQ: always allow promotion on HA queue during failover

When the RabbitMQ experience a rolling restart of its peers, the
master of an HA queue fails over from one replica to another.

If there are messages sent to the HA queue while some rabbit
nodes are restarting, the latter will reconnect as unsynchronized
slaves. It can happen that during a rolling restart, all rabbit
nodes reconnect as unsynchronized, which prevents RabbitMQ to
automatically elect a new Master for failover. This has other
side effects on fanout queues and may prevent OpenStack
notification to be consumed properly.

Change the HA policy to always allow a promotion even when all
replicas are unsynchronized. When such rare condition happens,
rely on OpenStack client to retry RPC if they need to.

Closes-Bug: #1823305
Co-Authored-By: Damien Ciabrini <dciabrin@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Id9bdd36aa0ee81424212e3a89185311817a15aee
(cherry picked from commit 610c8d8d41cd4b6bfd228ce1012416e424db625d)
(Resolved conflicts manually as cherry pick didn't apply cleanly)
"}]
commit_message:
RabbitMQ: always allow promotion on HA queue during failover

When the RabbitMQ experience a rolling restart of its peers, the
master of an HA queue fails over from one replica to another.

If there are messages sent to the HA queue while some rabbit
nodes are restarting, the latter will reconnect as unsynchronized
slaves. It can happen that during a rolling restart, all rabbit
nodes reconnect as unsynchronized, which prevents RabbitMQ to
automatically elect a new Master for failover. This has other
side effects on fanout queues and may prevent OpenStack
notification to be consumed properly.

Change the HA policy to always allow a promotion even when all
replicas are unsynchronized. When such rare condition happens,
rely on OpenStack client to retry RPC if they need to.

Closes-Bug: #1823305
Co-Authored-By: Damien Ciabrini <dciabrin@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Id9bdd36aa0ee81424212e3a89185311817a15aee
(cherry picked from commit 610c8d8d41cd4b6bfd228ce1012416e424db625d)
(Resolved conflicts manually as cherry pick didn't apply cleanly)

commit_message:
Ensure openstack clients are installed

We need to ensure the openstack clients are installed on controllers for
the deployed server case. This should be handled by the overcloud images
themselves, however if the images are not used we should make sure the
clients get installed with our OpenstackClients service.

This is not a clean cherry-pick from stable/stein. However,
it retains the contents from master. Please see a bugfix
committed via [1] for the cherry-pick to stable/stein.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/665177/

Change-Id: If7fad9f24c7294c2d749fc3838b1fb71182930fc
Related-Bug: #1829769
(cherry picked from commit 885715855b19ec71ab362d92233478f3afb5a696)
(cherry picked from commit fd56198717e48fbffdbd867a0aa7173f5d0ed314)

commit_message:
Do not invoke host config in agent config

The SR-IOV agent config was pulling in the host configuration which is
incorrect and will not work under certain conditions.

Change-Id: If5a0861441c1c33431364f2a1f3d7d1296106159
Closes-Bug: #1832335
(cherry picked from commit e9484ac78912cd0d403f0c2e931029afcecdbfd7)

(cherry picked from commit 0d67ecaf75d9375e2a88479514ce6cb7e910ec5e)

commit_message:
Disable iscsi.service to avoid iscsid on host from getting started

When some stale shutdown happens on the node, iscsi.service detects
remaining information about iscsi connection, and recovers connections
based on the information, with starting iscsid service on host.
This causes a collision between iscsid on host and iscsid in container,
which makes iscsid container keep restarting.

This patch makes sure that iscsi.service on host is disabled
when we deploy iscsid container, to avoid iscsid on host is started
unexpectedly.

Change-Id: I6c36cd15edfa53c3c76be9095ff40cecf451490d
Closes-Bug: #1833019
(cherry picked from commit 0d67ecaf75d9375e2a88479514ce6cb7e910ec5e)

commit_message:
Fix regression in list-changes

Recent merging of the liaison-loading code in list-changes makes
most list-changes job fail due to error in YAML loading code.

Beyond that YAML loading issue, the code assumes getting a dictionary
with team names as keys and an array of liaisons dictionary as values.
Fix the release_liaisons.yaml and schema to match.

Change-Id: I94fa41862d37aaf0535d64afd00b2bd55bb4649a

commit_message:
[api-ref] Fix nocatalog description for unscoped token

Unscoped token body never contains catalog, no matter the
nocatalog parameter is True or False.

This patch fixed the api-ref issue.

Change-Id: Ic3a09e3b25c20c5ac840f82631a1da1cbd1eb281

commit_message:
Import tripleo-bootstrap role

This change imports the tripleo-bootstrap role. Variables have been
broken-out into the new role structure which makes this role uniform
with other roles that have been created and imported.

* Molecule tests have been added to exercise this role on fed28 & cent7.

Change-Id: Ia9fe61d1793537796ff3fff8caf07ea7ea0a9dfd
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Put on hold the Ansible package update until is fixed

Package update for Ansible breaks[1] with:
Ansible 2.7 crashes on apt upgrade
because it upgrades itself to 2.8:
"fragment_class is None"

[1]: https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/56636

Change-Id: I1dabe448edfb118440b9ef1ee59c2e080d16ccf8
Closes-Bug: 1831589
(cherry picked from commit 53650f9635bc3b911e368a894603d7d07e3dec6a)

I think this is getting in shape now. My only concerns is about the REST APIs. I'd like to see some discussion with Chris or Ed from the API WG."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-10-29 16:10:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

(5 comments)

Some comments within about the API. The -1 is for the 401, which should be corrected.

The rest of it is commentary on the shape of the API, which may or may not be correct so doesn't warrant a -1, but may need some more discussion. In general it seems like the resources and representations thereof are too closely tied to the specific needs of the API, rather than a general way of providing an API to the resources involved."}, {'account_id': 25738, 'date': '2018-10-31 09:51:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(9 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2018-10-31 12:08:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 21672, 'date': '2018-11-05 13:51:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(5 comments)

Thanks, Chris. 

Re. "resources and representations thereof are too closely tied to the specific needs of the API", the general intention is to minimize the number of Nova -> Cyborg API calls for two reasons:
* More APIs == more touchpoints between Nova/Cyborg
* Fewer calls will (hopefully) help better scaling. Some of these calls are made in the Nova scheduler context and we don't want to affect instance creation/deletion throughput.

If you have ideas for improvement, please LMK.'}, {'account_id': 21672, 'date': '2018-11-05 13:52:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Thanks, Chris. 

Re. "resources and representations thereof are too closely tied to the specific needs of the API", the general intention is to minimize the number of Nova -> Cyborg API calls for two reasons:
* More APIs == more touchpoints between Nova/Cyborg
* Fewer calls will (hopefully) help better scaling. Some of these calls are made in the Nova scheduler context and we don't want to affect instance creation/deletion throughput.

If you have ideas for improvement, please LMK.'}, {'account_id': 21672, 'date': '2018-11-05 14:15:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(23 comments)

I'm trying to provide some feedback to this while at summit, so apologies for not catching up on all the conversation between now and the last time I looked at this. IMHO, this is really way too verbose and detailed. I know that's my usual thing, but... yeah.

I'm -1ing at least because I found a typo, but I hope this can be trimmed quite a bit. If you want another spec reviewer to come along and be able to digest and approve this in a reasonable amount of time, I think it needs to be cut down a lot."}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2018-11-14 15:45:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1

(21 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2018-11-14 16:02:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

(5 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-11-14 22:16:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1

(21 comments)

Sundar, I know you're not going to like my review here, but I have a whole lot of problems with this proposal.

In summary, I don't believe the proposed way of representing the concepts in Cyborg is a sound proposal. I'm uncomfortable with the fact that the device profile contains multiple resource requests groups. I'm uncomfortable with the concept of an "ARQ" when the thing it describes is more of just an attachment context. And I'm uncomfortable with the idea that os-acc is not focused on the low-level device plug/unplug functionality and is instead just a REST client for the Cyborg API (which I also don't think is well-thought-through at this time).

This all goes back to what I asked for in Denver from the Cyborg team: less focus on a REST API (which is mostly unnecessary at this point, IMHO) and more focus on getting an *actual* working low-level device attachment library going. I thought os-acc was going to be that thing, but I see no evidence yet that there is anything in os-acc or in the works for os-acc that will functionally allow a VM to attach a device to an FPGA resource context, a specialized SR-IOV VF, or any other type of accelerated device.

Until I see some evidence of a device attachment library that actually attaches and configures an accelerator device to a VM, I'm not supportive of any of the proposed changes to nova contained in this spec.

-jay'}, {'account_id': 21672, 'date': '2018-11-19 09:15:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

(43 comments)

* move bind to nova-compute
* use external events API rather than polling

I think we should either use this approach, or explain why that wouldn't work in the alternatives section. It is all about using similar patterns to how we want Cinder and Neutron interactions to work. I think it will be easier to maintain and operate if they all do the same kind of thing."}, {'account_id': 21672, 'date': '2019-05-14 05:45:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

There are obviously lots of implementation details that will need to be sorted out in code review but I've left some notes on high level things I think we'll want to sort out early, like which nova service creates ARQs (conductor?) and which one binds them (compute)."}, {'account_id': 21672, 'date': '2019-06-04 05:31:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

I didn't go through this thoroughly, just looked at what is needed to fix the seqdiag, see inline."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-06-04 16:20:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

(8 comments)

I think my main concerns at this point are:

1. Nova only creating ARQs during server create rather than the opposite of having changes to the API only for passing a pre-created ARQ id and having nova attach that, like an SR-IOV port. I'm not sure how much that has been debated already in the past, but assuming quite a bit. I'm not blocking on it but it's a concern.

2. To a lesser extent, and is an implementation detail, creating the ARQs in the conductor rather than the compute because as noted inline I think we want to avoid some of the problems we've had with managing external resources in the compute service (ports and volumes). But again I'm not blocking on that since it's an implementation detail."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-06-04 16:36:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-06-04 16:39:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

That might help clear up any confusion or worry about needing to re-write the API interaction based on my comments. tl;dr it sounds like the spec matches what has been previously discussed and agreed for the first version, I'm just catching up on all that. I think my concerns could be noted in the Alternatives section but we don't need to change course here."}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-06-05 13:44:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

commit_message:
Nova Cyborg interaction specification.

Describes the Nova - Cyborg interaction needed to create and manage
instances with accelerators, and the changes needed in Nova to
accomplish that.

Change-Id: Ibecee0d46e296813e90f855379a134b84d43a55f

commit_message:
Reword release note to use style of other notes

This patch also updates the link to keystoneauth1 code to use
git.openstack.org and point to a specific tag (I picked 3.4.0 which is
our lower constraint), so the link remains valid even if http.py is
renamed or deleted in future versions.

messages: [{'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-06-18 18:04:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17669, 'date': '2019-06-19 08:06:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 22629, 'date': '2019-06-19 20:36:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 30381, 'date': '2019-06-19 22:45:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 19779, 'date': '2019-06-20 13:10:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-18 18:04:01.000000000', 'message': "Fix keystone fernet key rotation scheduling

Right now every controller rotates fernet keys. This is nice because
should any controller die, we know the remaining ones will rotate the
keys. However, we are currently over-rotating the keys.

When we over rotate keys, we get logs like this:

 This is not a recognized Fernet token <token> TokenNotFound

Most clients can recover and get a new token, but some clients (like
Nova passing tokens to other services) can't do that because it doesn't
have the password to regenerate a new token.

With three controllers, in crontab in keystone-fernet we see the once a day
correctly staggered across the three controllers:

ssh ctrl1 sudo cat /etc/kolla/keystone-fernet/crontab
0 0 * * * /usr/bin/fernet-rotate.sh
ssh ctrl2 sudo cat /etc/kolla/keystone-fernet/crontab
0 8 * * * /usr/bin/fernet-rotate.sh
ssh ctrl3 sudo cat /etc/kolla/keystone-fernet/crontab
0 16 * * * /usr/bin/fernet-rotate.sh

Currently with three controllers we have this keystone config:

[token]
expiration = 86400 (although, keystone default is one hour)
allow_expired_window = 172800 (this is the keystone default)

[fernet_tokens]
max_active_keys = 4

Currently, kolla-ansible configures key rotation according to the following:

   rotation_interval = token_expiration / num_hosts

This means we rotate keys more quickly the more hosts we have, which doesn't
make much sense.

Keystone docs state:

   max_active_keys =
     ((token_expiration + allow_expired_window) / rotation_interval) + 2

For details see:
https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/stein/admin/fernet-token-faq.html

Rotation is based on pushing out a staging key, so should any server
start using that key, other servers will consider that valid. Then each
server in turn starts using the staging key, each in term demoting the
existing primary key to a secondary key. Eventually you prune the
secondary keys when there is no token in the wild that would need to be
decrypted using that key. So this all makes sense.

This change adds new variables for fernet_token_allow_expired_window and
fernet_key_rotation_interval, so that we can correctly calculate the
correct number of active keys. We now set the default rotation interval
so as to minimise the number of active keys to 3 - one primary, one
secondary, one buffer.

This change also fixes the fernet cron job generator, which was broken
in the following cases:

* requesting an interval of more than 1 day resulted in no jobs
* requesting an interval of more than 60 minutes, unless an exact
  multiple of 60 minutes, resulted in no jobs

It should now be possible to request any interval up to a week divided
by the number of hosts.

Change-Id: I10c82dc5f83653beb60ddb86d558c5602153341a
Closes-Bug: #1809469
(cherry picked from commit 6c1442c385450004dd253f3f464fe4336194be99)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix keystone fernet key rotation scheduling

Right now every controller rotates fernet keys. This is nice because
should any controller die, we know the remaining ones will rotate the
keys. However, we are currently over-rotating the keys.

When we over rotate keys, we get logs like this:

 This is not a recognized Fernet token <token> TokenNotFound

Most clients can recover and get a new token, but some clients (like
Nova passing tokens to other services) can't do that because it doesn't
have the password to regenerate a new token.

With three controllers, in crontab in keystone-fernet we see the once a day
correctly staggered across the three controllers:

ssh ctrl1 sudo cat /etc/kolla/keystone-fernet/crontab
0 0 * * * /usr/bin/fernet-rotate.sh
ssh ctrl2 sudo cat /etc/kolla/keystone-fernet/crontab
0 8 * * * /usr/bin/fernet-rotate.sh
ssh ctrl3 sudo cat /etc/kolla/keystone-fernet/crontab
0 16 * * * /usr/bin/fernet-rotate.sh

Currently with three controllers we have this keystone config:

[token]
expiration = 86400 (although, keystone default is one hour)
allow_expired_window = 172800 (this is the keystone default)

[fernet_tokens]
max_active_keys = 4

Currently, kolla-ansible configures key rotation according to the following:

   rotation_interval = token_expiration / num_hosts

This means we rotate keys more quickly the more hosts we have, which doesn't
make much sense.

Keystone docs state:

   max_active_keys =
     ((token_expiration + allow_expired_window) / rotation_interval) + 2

For details see:
https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/stein/admin/fernet-token-faq.html

Rotation is based on pushing out a staging key, so should any server
start using that key, other servers will consider that valid. Then each
server in turn starts using the staging key, each in term demoting the
existing primary key to a secondary key. Eventually you prune the
secondary keys when there is no token in the wild that would need to be
decrypted using that key. So this all makes sense.

This change adds new variables for fernet_token_allow_expired_window and
fernet_key_rotation_interval, so that we can correctly calculate the
correct number of active keys. We now set the default rotation interval
so as to minimise the number of active keys to 3 - one primary, one
secondary, one buffer.

This change also fixes the fernet cron job generator, which was broken
in the following cases:

* requesting an interval of more than 1 day resulted in no jobs
* requesting an interval of more than 60 minutes, unless an exact
  multiple of 60 minutes, resulted in no jobs

It should now be possible to request any interval up to a week divided
by the number of hosts.

Change-Id: I10c82dc5f83653beb60ddb86d558c5602153341a
Closes-Bug: #1809469
(cherry picked from commit 6c1442c385450004dd253f3f464fe4336194be99)

commit_message:
Add unit test for keystone fernet cron generator

Before making changes to this script, document its behaviour with a unit
test.

There are two major issues:

* requesting an interval of more than 1 day results in no jobs
* requesting an interval of more than 60 minutes, unless an exact
  multiple of 60 minutes, results in no jobs

Change-Id: I655da1102dfb4ca12437b7db0b79c9a61568f79e
Related-Bug: #1809469
(cherry picked from commit 25ac955a4e2645da29f8c7b807f0bac5afb43838)

commit_message:
Adds pypi packages validation and upload

This adds validation of packaging and a `tox -e upload` option that
can be used to publish new versions.

It is key to lint packaging on each change in order to prevent changes
that could break it.

Change-Id: If3fd01fa7d8b006c527d905b637a688cc9ca7151

commit_message:

sphinx 2.0 no longer supports Python 2.7.
2. Replace git.openstack.org URLs with opendev.org URLs

Change-Id: Id9f496f57acd2d5a388920e6bdebe52c40a98073

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-19 22:46:50.000000000', 'message': "cleanup pyc/pyo files

Horizon is relying on Django app registry to manage its plugins.
Django, in turn, is using Horizon's setting util to load
the app configurations.

https://github.com/openstack/horizon/blob/master/openstack_dashboard
/utils/settings.py

It basically uses pkgutil to load any kind of Python files under the
openstack_dashboard/enabled dir. However, if the package does not cleanup
its compiled Python files (i.e. pyc and pyo), it will lead to problems
during upgrade where the new package is using the same app lable that is
occupied by an old pyc/pyo file that got left behind. Therefore, sensible
thing to do would be to cleanup those old pyc/pyo files prior to running
manage.py.

Change-Id: Id3253e69a2eb225844fa7ca0a71185115abdc24f
"}]
commit_message:
cleanup pyc/pyo files

Horizon is relying on Django app registry to manage its plugins.
Django, in turn, is using Horizon's setting util to load
the app configurations.

https://github.com/openstack/horizon/blob/master/openstack_dashboard
/utils/settings.py

It basically uses pkgutil to load any kind of Python files under the
openstack_dashboard/enabled dir. However, if the package does not cleanup
its compiled Python files (i.e. pyc and pyo), it will lead to problems
during upgrade where the new package is using the same app lable that is
occupied by an old pyc/pyo file that got left behind. Therefore, sensible
thing to do would be to cleanup those old pyc/pyo files prior to running
manage.py.

Change-Id: Id3253e69a2eb225844fa7ca0a71185115abdc24f

LGTM, but for my understanding, why mocking the time module is not a good idea ?'}, {'account_id': 8543, 'date': '2019-05-08 13:35:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

We'd risk causing unexpected behavior when tests (especially functional tests) are polling for things such as external processes, maybe having timeouts as well.

Mocking utcnow instead of time.time or time.sleep is probably safer and may be worth considering. Still, I'm not sure if it's entirely safe to mock utcnow globally using a fixture."}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2019-06-20 14:33:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Thank you!!'}]

commit_message:
Windows: fix flaky tests

Some tests compare timestamps (e.g. image created_at/updated_at
fields).

In some cases, subsequent timestamps may be identical, breaking the
assertions made by those tests.

One idea is to just add a 1ms sleep which should be a negligeable.
Mocking the functions used to retrieve timestamps may be undesireable.

For now, we'll do this only for Windows, where time.time has a lower
resolution compared to Linux (1e-7 as opposed to 1e-9).

At the same time, socket timeouts are rather inconsistent on Windows.
When a timeout is hit, recv may either throw ConnectionAbortedError
*or* return nothing. This needs to be taken into account when
expecting socket timeouts.

Change-Id: Ie5a4d8fb4c979c09eda2fdc0fad0baa1d1840c59

commit_message:
Move failing check jobs to experimental

There are currently 4 check jobs that are contantly failing.
These jobs both make the check take longer and waste compute power during build.
I have moved them to experimental, and once we get them to not fail, we can
move them back to their place at the check queue.

Change-Id: I00d80d58ededc0fd4b08ed137addabc97dbec145

commit_message:
Dont empty out a symlink

Modifying the content of this symlink will just
cause a warning and not do anything since the
sites-available file is empty already.

Change-Id: I82e573ca66af4485303ec9c0040e2e0063d93585

commit_message:
Make reno and docs conform to cookiecutter

This patch adds release notes management to OSH [1].

When using the standard dependencies, the documentation's conf.py
had to be adapted to remove oslophinx.

While going over documentation to adapt those changes, I could
apply doc8, which is now included when running `tox -e docs`.
This now enforces documentation quality in the gates.

The documentation was therefore made doc8 compliant, mostly by
replacing tabs to spaces, and ensuring the line length didn't
exceed the recommended 79 chars, which was practically already
applied in most files, with a few exceptions fixed here.

[1]: https://docs.openstack.org/project-team-guide/release-management.html#managing-release-notes

Co-Authored-By: Jean-Philippe Evrard <jean-philippe@evrard.me>
Change-Id: Ib9253611df08257f2b418a0d9e5e817a232c011b

[{'created': '2019-05-20 21:10:57.000000000', 'message': "s3api: stop adding etag quotes when there are already etag quotes

Some middleware, such as that included with ProxyFS, may put
RFC-compliant ETags in container listings; we should leave those
unquoted, so we don't double-up on quotes.

Change-Id: I8b56231aef41076a224dc62cd93c1973355c4670
"}]
commit_message:
s3api: stop adding etag quotes when there are already etag quotes

Some middleware, such as that included with ProxyFS, may put
RFC-compliant ETags in container listings; we should leave those
unquoted, so we don't double-up on quotes.

Change-Id: I8b56231aef41076a224dc62cd93c1973355c4670

commit_message:
Log disk transfer stats in live migration monitor.

Current logs in live migration monitor only show the
memory transfer stats, but sometimes we also want to
see the disk transfer stats from log rather than by
some other ways like `nova server-migration-show` or
`virsh domjobinfo`.

Note that we don't include disk transfer stats in
the progress percentage calculation, just log them.

Change-Id: I3b3ac36b84f087f7a2d644706feac886cded18f4
Signed-off-by: Fan Zhang <zh.f@outlook.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-20 08:37:29.000000000', 'message': 'Reduce OVH BHS1 pool size to 120

OVH is having issues on some hypervisors on OSF aggregate.
As a result, the others hypervisors are under heavy load and some
instances are not able to boot correctly.
To avoid this, I propose to reduce the number of instance to 120 for a
while.

Change-Id: Ic5f4b279e7222e9ec242aeb80e69612d2e6ef70f
Signed-off-by: Arnaud Morin <arnaud.morin@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Reduce OVH BHS1 pool size to 120

OVH is having issues on some hypervisors on OSF aggregate.
As a result, the others hypervisors are under heavy load and some
instances are not able to boot correctly.
To avoid this, I propose to reduce the number of instance to 120 for a
while.

Change-Id: Ic5f4b279e7222e9ec242aeb80e69612d2e6ef70f
Signed-off-by: Arnaud Morin <arnaud.morin@gmail.com>

commit_message:
cell_mapping - wrap IPv6 address in format_url

The urlparse library removes brackets the user placed in
CONF.database.connection which is passed in as 'default'.

This change ensures that _format_url function will wrap an
IPv6 address 'hostname' in the connection url in brackets.

To ensure compatibility with existing templated cell mapping
urls that include the brackets, any '[{hostname}]' substring
in a database_connection is replaced with '{hostname}'.

Closes-Bug: #1831315
Change-Id: Ib1e2cfcca014cbb005ba2c06ef2e00148fc22091

to point to the plugin parameters. Finally, the keystone v2 API was
dropped[3], so reference the v3 API.

commit_message:
Update keystone_authtoken config reference

The auth_uri parameter of keystonemiddleware was renamed to
'www_authenticate_uri'[1], so update the documentation accordingly.
Additionally, the identity_uri parameter was deprecated in favor of
using a keystoneauth plugin[2], so this change updates the documentation
to point to the plugin parameters. Finally, the keystone v2 API was
dropped[3], so reference the v3 API.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/508522
[2] https://review.opendev.org/127066
[3] https://review.opendev.org/572846

Change-Id: I146e6d92008409ce219b18caaaa643c7f4496054

[{'created': '2019-06-12 12:23:56.000000000', 'message': "Use 'dnf repoquery' when system uses DNF

repoquery is part of dnf so we can use 'dnf repoquery' directly rather
than install dnf-utils, which isn't installed by default on e.g. RHEL8.

When using yum, command -v repoquery will still be used as it was
before this update.

Change-Id: Iea8822084988b23652e6d3f8b5828c05734158af
"}]
commit_message:
Use 'dnf repoquery' when system uses DNF

repoquery is part of dnf so we can use 'dnf repoquery' directly rather
than install dnf-utils, which isn't installed by default on e.g. RHEL8.

When using yum, command -v repoquery will still be used as it was
before this update.

Change-Id: Iea8822084988b23652e6d3f8b5828c05734158af

commit_message:
Fix workflow execution cascade delete error

If the cascade deletion error is identified, then resort to
recursively deleting the subworkflows before deleting the
given execution.

Closes-Bug: https://bugs.launchpad.net/mistral/+bug/1832300
Change-Id: I6e0d9db93e103eaf3a329dfa1b4153975c135008

subject: Rename rhsm_repository module to avoid conflict.
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-20 09:34:14.000000000', 'message': "Rename rhsm_repository module to avoid conflict.

The rhsm_repository is now part of the Ansible installation,
however, the version used inside the redhat_subscription role
contains changes the defaul module from Ansible doesn't contain.

As a consequence, if in the playbook execution, some task makes
use of the rhsm_repository module Ansible will locate it inside
its default module libraries and when we get to the point of invoking
the module from ansible-role-redhat-subscription/tasks/portal.yml
it will find out that the module is already loaded and make use
of the Ansible one, instead of the module stored under library/
rhsm_repository.py. This is a temporary solution until we'll update
into Ansible 2.8 for queens and rocky, then both modules will be
in sync and the one from ansible-role-redhat-subscription/library
could be removed.

Change-Id: Id53ebefff1f992781171a1e760fbf5306020cb56
Closes-Bug: #1833519

commit_message:
Rename rhsm_repository module to avoid conflict.

The rhsm_repository is now part of the Ansible installation,
however, the version used inside the redhat_subscription role
contains changes the defaul module from Ansible doesn't contain.

As a consequence, if in the playbook execution, some task makes
use of the rhsm_repository module Ansible will locate it inside
its default module libraries and when we get to the point of invoking
the module from ansible-role-redhat-subscription/tasks/portal.yml
it will find out that the module is already loaded and make use
of the Ansible one, instead of the module stored under library/
rhsm_repository.py. This is a temporary solution until we'll update
into Ansible 2.8 for queens and rocky, then both modules will be
in sync and the one from ansible-role-redhat-subscription/library
could be removed.

Change-Id: Id53ebefff1f992781171a1e760fbf5306020cb56
Closes-Bug: #1833519

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-14 16:38:28.000000000', 'message': "Fix lower-constraints test fail due to failing dep build

Ubuntu Bionic updated OpenSSL package to new release:
from 1.1.0 to 1.1.1
It caused cryptography in version from lower-constraints
to fail to build in Zuul.
Additionally, constrained cryptography version did not
match the requirement for constrained PyOpenSSL.
This commit bumps the version to the minimum required
by constrained PyOpenSSL.
It works because manylinux1 (binary) wheel exists.
This version agrees also with upper-constraints for Queens.

Dependency on cryptography is removed as it is not used directly
by kolla (and requirements checker requires lower-constraints
matching version - let's not create an illusion of usage).

For stable/stein additionally fix version of sphinx to pass CI.

For stable/{rocky,queens} this does not necessarily affect CI but
may affect local testing and/or docs generation.

Adapted for stable/queens which has no lower-constraints nor
doc/requirements.txt

Change-Id: I8ae19f212049cae5dfb4e8dd6ec6cd14a8c46e0e
Signed-off-by: Radosław Piliszek <radoslaw.piliszek@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 39a2cf066c4c79436629017155302d36243aa338)
"}, {'created': '2019-06-18 17:51:23.000000000', 'message': "Fix lower-constraints test fail due to failing dep build

Ubuntu Bionic updated OpenSSL package to new release:
from 1.1.0 to 1.1.1
It caused cryptography in version from lower-constraints
to fail to build in Zuul.
Additionally, constrained cryptography version did not
match the requirement for constrained PyOpenSSL.
This commit bumps the version to the minimum required
by constrained PyOpenSSL.
It works because manylinux1 (binary) wheel exists.
This version agrees also with upper-constraints for Queens.

Dependency on cryptography is removed as it is not used directly
by kolla (and requirements checker requires lower-constraints
matching version - let's not create an illusion of usage).

For stable/stein additionally fix version of sphinx to pass CI.

For stable/{rocky,queens} this does not necessarily affect CI but
may affect local testing and/or docs generation.

Adapted for stable/queens which has no lower-constraints nor
doc/requirements.txt

Change-Id: I8ae19f212049cae5dfb4e8dd6ec6cd14a8c46e0e
Signed-off-by: Radosław Piliszek <radoslaw.piliszek@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 39a2cf066c4c79436629017155302d36243aa338)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix lower-constraints test fail due to failing dep build

Ubuntu Bionic updated OpenSSL package to new release:
from 1.1.0 to 1.1.1
It caused cryptography in version from lower-constraints
to fail to build in Zuul.
Additionally, constrained cryptography version did not
match the requirement for constrained PyOpenSSL.
This commit bumps the version to the minimum required
by constrained PyOpenSSL.
It works because manylinux1 (binary) wheel exists.
This version agrees also with upper-constraints for Queens.

Dependency on cryptography is removed as it is not used directly
by kolla (and requirements checker requires lower-constraints
matching version - let's not create an illusion of usage).

For stable/stein additionally fix version of sphinx to pass CI.

For stable/{rocky,queens} this does not necessarily affect CI but
may affect local testing and/or docs generation.

Adapted for stable/queens which has no lower-constraints nor
doc/requirements.txt

Change-Id: I8ae19f212049cae5dfb4e8dd6ec6cd14a8c46e0e
Signed-off-by: Radosław Piliszek <radoslaw.piliszek@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 39a2cf066c4c79436629017155302d36243aa338)

[{'account_id': 22165, 'date': '2017-04-02 03:31:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-04-02 04:27:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-kolla-ansible-docs-ubuntu-xenial http://docs-draft.openstack.org/06/452506/1/check/gate-kolla-ansible-docs-ubuntu-xenial/a2892b8//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 50s

- gate-kolla-ansible-python27-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/06/452506/1/check/gate-kolla-ansible-python27-ubuntu-xenial/927f813/ : SUCCESS in 50s

- gate-kolla-ansible-dsvm-deploy-centos-source-centos-7-nv http://logs.openstack.org/06/452506/1/check/gate-kolla-ansible-dsvm-deploy-centos-source-centos-7-nv/28cfb38/ : SUCCESS in 21m 39s (non-voting)
- gate-kolla-ansible-dsvm-deploy-ubuntu-binary-ubuntu-xenial-nv http://logs.openstack.org/06/452506/1/check/gate-kolla-ansible-dsvm-deploy-ubuntu-binary-ubuntu-xenial-nv/b46ab8d/ : SUCCESS in 13m 27s (non-voting)
- gate-kolla-ansible-dsvm-deploy-ubuntu-source-ubuntu-xenial-nv http://logs.openstack.org/06/452506/1/check/gate-kolla-ansible-dsvm-deploy-ubuntu-source-ubuntu-xenial-nv/a2d319f/ : SUCCESS in 13m 35s (non-voting)
- gate-kolla-ansible-dsvm-deploy-oraclelinux-binary-centos-7-nv http://logs.openstack.org/06/452506/1/check/gate-kolla-ansible-dsvm-deploy-oraclelinux-binary-centos-7-nv/f4d8230/ : SUCCESS in 21m 21s (non-voting)
- gate-kolla-ansible-dsvm-deploy-oraclelinux-source-centos-7-nv http://logs.openstack.org/06/452506/1/check/gate-kolla-ansible-dsvm-deploy-oraclelinux-source-centos-7-nv/b4844b1/ : SUCCESS in 21m 30s (non-voting)'}, {'account_id': 21691, 'date': '2017-04-03 11:57:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 19316, 'date': '2017-04-05 12:08:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 23717, 'date': '2017-04-10 01:11:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 22959, 'date': '2017-04-10 03:07:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8157, 'date': '2017-04-10 09:29:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Sorry but I don't see where is the results status check. 
You perform network entities creation and deletion without testing resources status. 
Just state absent or present seems tested, this is not enough."}, {'account_id': 8157, 'date': '2017-04-10 13:05:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Resources can be created in ERROR state, and remove from ERROR state.'}, {'account_id': 22165, 'date': '2017-04-10 13:47:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Resources can be created in ERROR state, and remove from ERROR
 > state.

it won't be happen,  the ansible wait until the requested resource is complete

- wait 
        Should ansible wait until the requested resource is complete. (Choices: yes, no) [Default: yes]"}, {'account_id': 8157, 'date': '2017-04-10 15:14:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@caoyuan: "ansible wait until the requested resource is complete" doesn't mean resource is ACTIVE. I am wrong?'}, {'account_id': 19316, 'date': '2017-04-10 15:39:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

As far I see, ansible modules will only wait until the resource is stored in the database and API gives an OK answer status.
There is no way to poll resource creation in neutron during resource creation and the network creation message can be OK, but the network is in error state.
Think this need testing to ensure the resources are active'}, {'account_id': 19316, 'date': '2017-04-10 15:58:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

In a conversation with Bertrand, we saw that we can ensure the resource is Active iterating over returned results.
http://docs.ansible.com/ansible/os_network_module.html#return-values

with a register and until, we can wait until the resource is active.

** Untested example:
register: example_network
until: example_network.results.status == ACTIVE
**

or something similar, haven't tried yet."}, {'account_id': 8157, 'date': '2017-04-10 16:22:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thank you Eduardo: I don't known what is the real scope of this "check" task. But if it purpose is to check that services are UP and RUNNING, in Neutron case testing network and subnet creation doesn't reflect the "health" of the Neutron service. 
This resources are "always" created successfully, but it doesn't mean network is up and running.
To check Neutron health, the basic test will be for example to create a router, plug this router to a public network, and ping the router IP.
For a first step creating a router, plugging it to a public network and testing port status ACTIVE, will be great.
With this scenario you'll have test that L2 network is UP and works.
For L3 part more works is needed, regards'}, {'account_id': 1390, 'date': '2017-04-10 16:59:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> I don't known what is the real scope of this "check" task.
The scope of these are very simple smoke tests. Right now we can do a deploy, ansible will finish green, but a neutron container can be stuck restarting. We are trying to at least mitigate this, if we can also check that the service works at a basic level that is good also. Testing much more that this will begin to move into duplicating work done elsewhere such as tempest, and is outside the scope of these checks.

> For a first step creating a router, plugging it to a public network and testing port status ACTIVE, will be great.
Based on my description above, I agree, this is exactly what we need.'}, {'account_id': 1390, 'date': '2017-04-10 17:01:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-06-27 13:29:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified-1

Merge Failed.

This change or one of its cross-repo dependencies was unable to be automatically merged with the current state of its repository. Please rebase the change and upload a new patchset.'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2017-12-18 02:58:33.000000000', 'content': 'Removed reviewer Jenkins with the following votes:

* Verified-1 by Jenkins (3)
'}, {'account_id': 28587, 'date': '2018-07-03 06:12:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

[{'created': '2017-04-02 03:31:15.000000000', 'message': "Add neutron sanity check to use built in shade

The current module 'kolla_sanity' was written as a shim before full
shade support was added to Ansible. This should now no longer be needed,
we can implement the checks using Ansible provided modules.

Change-Id: I88539fea0a9eb809f12b6b77ea5a8f63dbf27778

commit_message:
Add neutron sanity check into kolla-ansible

1. create a test network
2. create a subnet belong to test
3. add a interface into router with wait is true

Change-Id: I88539fea0a9eb809f12b6b77ea5a8f63dbf27778
Partially-implements: blueprint sanity-check-container

commit_message:
use include_tasks instead of include

include is marked as deprecated since ansible 2.4[0]

Switch to include_tasks or import_playbook as necessary

[0] https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/2.4/include_module.html#deprecated

Change-Id: I0de2c4ddc6b64f112c5e1f5d67856f4480a3d325

commit_message:
Add the wait parameter to wait the tasks completed

when the wait is true, ansible(shade) will wait the
status become available (for cinder volume, the others
is similar)

Change-Id: I79f589a76c2e8ebbbe7fc117416a58645a6643e2

commit_message:
Document running tests with stestr

Use of stestr is increasingly common within OpenStack:

    http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-September/122135.html

so document how to use it ahead of the docs for testr and nose, and
add deprecation notices to the latter two.

Also apply some minor formatting tweaks in the same context.

Change-Id: I9aa3b2c4ce636d94bdf1320b8eaf28af113fc036

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-13 19:04:05.000000000', 'message': "Ingress: Remove prometheus-nginx.socket on start

This updates the ingress chart's start script to remove any
prexisting prometheus-nginx.socket files. This was done to address
issues seen when nodes are rebooted and when ingress pods were
forcibly deleted, where the rescheduled pods wouldn't be able to
mount the socket for exposing prometheus metrics due to the socket
from the previous pod still existing. This behavior was seen when
the pod is run as a daemonset on each host

Change-Id: Ifbb9f4734beb462650299ebee671bc099b086bf8
Signed-off-by: Steve Wilkerson <sw5822@att.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Ingress: Remove prometheus-nginx.socket on start

This updates the ingress chart's start script to remove any
prexisting prometheus-nginx.socket files. This was done to address
issues seen when nodes are rebooted and when ingress pods were
forcibly deleted, where the rescheduled pods wouldn't be able to
mount the socket for exposing prometheus metrics due to the socket
from the previous pod still existing. This behavior was seen when
the pod is run as a daemonset on each host

Change-Id: Ifbb9f4734beb462650299ebee671bc099b086bf8
Signed-off-by: Steve Wilkerson <sw5822@att.com>

[{'created': '2019-06-05 15:49:38.000000000', 'message': "Add Tempest gate with lower-constraints

Numerous times we hit issues when testing packaged versions of Kuryr
that use dependencies with versions between our lower-constraints.txt
and global requirements/upper-constraints.txt. Each time we found
issues and that's because our lower-constraints gate was not functional.
To further increase test coverage of lower-constraints this commit adds
a functional gate that will run Kuryr with old dependencies.

This is implemented by simply overwriting UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE
build-arg when building Kuryr containers.

Change-Id: Ic148020d1a0ec98150d8c61b21bbbe44b7be2075

commit_message:
Add Tempest gate with lower-constraints

Numerous times we hit issues when testing packaged versions of Kuryr
that use dependencies with versions between our lower-constraints.txt
and global requirements/upper-constraints.txt. Each time we found
issues and that's because our lower-constraints gate was not functional.
To further increase test coverage of lower-constraints this commit adds
a functional gate that will run Kuryr with old dependencies.

This is implemented by simply overwriting UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE
build-arg when building Kuryr containers.

Besides that cotyledon's minimum version is raised to 1.5.0 as we're
actively using a feature added back then (it was in late 2016, so we
should be safe here).

Change-Id: Ic148020d1a0ec98150d8c61b21bbbe44b7be2075

[{'created': '2019-06-16 18:17:08.000000000', 'message': 'Optimize finding upstream task executions

This commit introduces next optimizations:
1. No need to send a request if the list of inbound tasks is empty.
2. Instead of checking already downloaded tasks, it is more reasonable
to add filters to the request.
3. Generation of task execution cache is meaningless here, because
we only check the nearest tasks without going up the graph.

Change-Id: I5cb144903cd2abb6eecfe32a13da4a2ebf7db3dc
'}]
commit_message:
Optimize finding upstream task executions

This commit introduces next optimizations:
1. No need to send a request if the list of inbound tasks is empty.
2. Instead of checking already downloaded tasks, it is more reasonable
to add filters to the request.
3. Generation of task execution cache is meaningless here, because
we only check the nearest tasks without going up the graph.

Change-Id: I5cb144903cd2abb6eecfe32a13da4a2ebf7db3dc

commit_message:
Update SUSE install documentation

openSUSE and SLES have Placement packages, but they are named slightly
differently and the default Apache configuration is slightly different
than what was documented. See the package definition in OBS[1]. This
patch makes those corrections.

[1] https://build.opensuse.org/package/show/Cloud:OpenStack:Stein/openstack-placement

Change-Id: Id0eca721d850d849c7a273683c7f393e5a216682

subject: Remove overly-verbose allocation request log
messages:
[{'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-06-19 13:03:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-06-19 13:04:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

If this log message is important for some reason, please say so and we'll just keep it, but I couldn't think of specific way in which it was adding useful info."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-19 13:58:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

TBH this doesn't seem super onerous to me, at debug level, if my cloud is big. But suggestion inline for taking a little bit of the sting off."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-06-19 14:13:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > TBH this doesn't seem super onerous to me, at debug level, if my
 > cloud is big. But suggestion inline for taking a little bit of the
 > sting off.

In the example where I discovered this, 100 GET /ac requests led to >29000 lines of this emission.

While the numbers are annoying enough, what is more annoying is that it is not clear to me what value even 1 emission gives us. What is a debugging going to be able to do with that information. All we have is a root uuid and a count of allocation requests. What can I do with that?

Unless we can come up with concrete use for it, I think we should kill it, even if TRACE[1].

(We've not yet broached the lower levels and I think doing so for just this would be bogus. Either it is useful, or it is not.)"}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-06-19 14:14:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Sorry, forgot to also say: What value would a summary at intervals provide?'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-06-19 16:41:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Have a look at the 95M log file on http://logs.openstack.org/95/665695/8/check/placement-nested-perfload/6617312/logs/placement-api.log for a bit more info on why this might be overkill

If we remove these lines it shrinks to 7.9M (which still seems like a lot but there is a lot going on)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-19 19:40:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

> What is a debugging going to be able to do with that information. All we have is a root uuid and a count of allocation requests. What can I do with that?

IMO the interesting piece of information is knowing how many candidates are coming from each host. In the examples you've shown, it's always 1, because either not nested or limiting to a single NUMA by trait. Seeing >1 tells me I could be hitting NUMA nodes, or multiple sharing providers, or whatever.

If I turned on DEBUG, presumably it's because I'm trying to debug something. Like why I never seem to land an instance on host X. Seeing 0 here in particular tells me that the final trait check failed me.

BUT

the debug logs in _check_traits_for_alloc_request cover that. (Note that those will probably also jangle your "overly verbose" nerve when we're using traits to narrow down to a small number of hosts in a large cloud.)

And in any case I'm really just playing devil's advocate here. +2 we can remove this message.

> What value would a summary at intervals provide?

Not sure what you mean by "intervals". I was suggesting one summary message at the end of _alloc_candidates_multiple_providers saying "got $c candidates across $r roots". This would show up right after [1] which says the same thing; so different numbers tell me how much filtering _alloc_candidates_multiple_providers actually did.

That could be done in a fup, though.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/placement/src/branch/master/placement/objects/research_context.py#L529-L533'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-19 19:42:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck rax apt mirror?'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-06-20 11:02:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Remove overly-verbose allocation request log

In I952d5229d6c40588cde6197683117a7e19127939 an "got %d
allocation requests under root provider %s" log message was added.
It reports a log line for every allocation request under every
root provider in the candidates. In a large but sparsely used
cloud this generates a large number of log lines (see the identified
story for more details and links to examples), well more than 75%
of the lines in a log.

The information added by this particular line is not nearly as
useful as the other lines added in the change identified above.
So here, in this change, it is removed.

Change-Id: I4aee9de5b19045e6e773349e8f77ccb7f359d360
Story: 2005918
Task: 34179

commit_message:
Refactor import_authorized_keys() function for performance

The main change is to fetch all of the relation_data() at once, and then
iterate through the python dictionary.  This speeds up processing of
potentially hundreds of hosts and authorized_keys.

Change-Id: I095104f535c1eae1554f842502ae93ebb92e44fe
Related-Bug: #1833420

commit_message:
Adds validation of release config files

This adds tests for release config images which would run as part of
the existing tox-molecule job.

While this first version of release-config validation is calling
ansible directly, we could consider migrating it to molecule when the
need arises (like adding tests which need to run on specific platforms)

This also points the missing fedora28 images to centos7 until we get
them fixed (or remove the configs).

This replace old molecule test discovery code which is now done by
pytest-molecule plugin.

Story: https://tree.taiga.io/project/tripleo-ci-board/task/979
Change-Id: I36df81e2c8839f54abf8556e011c026ea505fcdb
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/666220/

commit_message:
Add new parameter NovaLiveMigrationWaitForVIFPlug

Add parameter NovaLiveMigrationWaitForVIFPlug which allows to set
`compute/live_migration_wait_for_vif_plug` which in turn allows
whether to wait for ``network-vif-plugged`` events before
starting guest transfer.

The default value for the parameter is set to true and it is
set to false when `ovn` is in `NeutronMechanismDrivers` list.

Depends-On: I0048d1f57eeb3418b52f225f87810ea1a7250a0f
Change-Id: I1ce38ea3ef6ba40625adc8da90903aac397cf60e

[{'created': '2019-06-17 13:42:58.000000000', 'message': 'Increase timeout of temp swift URLs from 1 to 4 hours

It can take longer than 1 hour for a temporary swift
URL which stores the backup of the fetch directory to
be created vs used. Increase the timeout from 1 hour
to 4 hours so that the URL does not expire before it
is used.

Change-Id: Ib989bd673c694a9dc5af2a4a63ed84888f102a50
Fixes-Bug: #1832509
(cherry picked from commit 8f2e1064a2473a8218056ecfd932c714b11e0fe6)
'}]
commit_message:
Increase timeout of temp swift URLs from 1 to 4 hours

It can take longer than 1 hour for a temporary swift
URL which stores the backup of the fetch directory to
be created vs used. Increase the timeout from 1 hour
to 4 hours so that the URL does not expire before it
is used.

Change-Id: Ib989bd673c694a9dc5af2a4a63ed84888f102a50
Fixes-Bug: #1832509
(cherry picked from commit 8f2e1064a2473a8218056ecfd932c714b11e0fe6)

commit_message:
Increase timeout of temp swift URLs from 1 to 4 hours

It can take longer than 1 hour for a temporary swift
URL which stores the backup of the fetch directory to
be created vs used. Increase the timeout from 1 hour
to 4 hours so that the URL does not expire before it
is used.

Change-Id: Ib989bd673c694a9dc5af2a4a63ed84888f102a50
Fixes-Bug: #1832509
(cherry picked from commit 8f2e1064a2473a8218056ecfd932c714b11e0fe6)

commit_message:
Update json module to jsonutils

oslo project provide jsonutils, and qinlingclient  use it in many place[1],
this PS to update the remained json module to oslo jsonutils for
consistency.

[1]: https://github.com/openstack/python-qinlingclient/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=jsonutils&type=

Change-Id: I16cb1e688f0b237d270acb6751e78d6b4a5d01ba

[{'created': '2019-06-18 19:46:25.000000000', 'message': 'Fix handling of SR-IOV PF routes

Routes on SR-IOV PF interfaces were being ignored in
impl_ifcfg.py. This change adds route handling for SR-IOV
interfaces, and a unit test to test writing route files.

Closes-bug: 1831951
Change-Id: If41178105229fb9adce9c2950aab39fc55b56166
(cherry picked from commit b04d8f30d4993fba3e4d207ca698cf10bdf69c2b)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix handling of SR-IOV PF routes

Routes on SR-IOV PF interfaces were being ignored in
impl_ifcfg.py. This change adds route handling for SR-IOV
interfaces, and a unit test to test writing route files.

Closes-bug: 1831951
Change-Id: If41178105229fb9adce9c2950aab39fc55b56166
(cherry picked from commit b04d8f30d4993fba3e4d207ca698cf10bdf69c2b)

[{'created': '2019-03-13 14:31:09.000000000', 'message': "Setup cluster definition based on the ansible limit option.

During upgrade we're re-creating the pacemaker cluster one node at a
time. So we need to override the cluster definition. We do this by
collecting the ansible_limit variable and mapping the controller
defined as member of the cluster.

Co-Authored-By: Jose Luis Franco Arza <jfrancoa@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Iece3451d3a99929ab364b23f61ef6cbc5fa0cf04
Implements: blueprint upgrades-with-os

Change-Id: I3cfd4272449b207874723682903505d2bbdb435b

commit_message:
Setup cluster definition based on the ansible limit option.

During upgrade we're re-creating the pacemaker cluster one node at a
time. So we need to override the cluster definition. We do this by
collecting the ansible_limit variable and mapping the controller
defined as member of the cluster.

Co-Authored-By: Jose Luis Franco Arza <jfrancoa@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Jiri Stransky <jistr@redhat.com>
Implements: blueprint upgrades-with-os
Closes-Bug: #1832361
Depends-On: Ibd95f4536c033af2094bd079cc81eeba18a36352
Depends-On: Ia108af3799dfd1be24c6ea738e42f0cde19c90c3
Depends-On: I3fa0717203f3f6eae852d019bec71e97eb485aa2
Change-Id: I3cfd4272449b207874723682903505d2bbdb435b

commit_message:
Mark kolla-build-*-source jobs non-voting

Ocata only

All build jobs are failing on Ocata, and we cannot disable the image
publishing jobs without removing them or marking as non-voting.

Change-Id: I52b1bf9b7b92b0874d7a59f0d6fa786368e82d2f

commit_message:
[heat] Multi-region support for bootstrap

When bootstrapping, Heat was not setting a region explicitly, so it
could default to a region other than the one being deployed.

Change-Id: I0a0596a020fbff91ccc5b9f44f271eab220c88cd
(cherry picked from commit 44da1963ba3d089e0fc646c1b1c1fb712f1c8173)

commit_message:
Remove mock of not existing method in L3 agent UT.

There was mock of ri._get_floatingips_bound_to_host() in
L3 test_agent unit test module. This method was removed long time
ago in [1] so this mock is not necessary anymore.

TrivialFix

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/499725/

Change-Id: Ia93cab667f8154663ba62b78bc0329ee16b8202c

[{'created': '2019-06-18 11:21:27.000000000', 'message': 'Ingest non-standard Monasca logs

Presently, errors can appear in Fluentd and Monasca Log API logs due
to log output from some Monasca services, which do not use Oslo log,
being processed alongside other OpenStack logs which do.

This change parses these log files separately to prevent these errors.

'}]
commit_message:
Ingest non-standard Monasca logs

Presently, errors can appear in Fluentd and Monasca Log API logs due
to log output from some Monasca services, which do not use Oslo log,
being processed alongside other OpenStack logs which do.

This change parses these log files separately to prevent these errors.

Change-Id: Ie3cbb51424989b01727b5ebaaeba032767073462

commit_message:
Add agent timestamp to "_log_heartbeat" method

When an agent reports the state, the timestamp is sent along with the
agent status. This timestamp now is logged if "log_agent_heartbeats" is
activated.

Change-Id: Ifc88dfb3041aa07b197f395172b69399796ba46a
Related-Bug: #1799555

commit_message:
Mark multisite test bundles as dev

Move multisite test bundles to dev section; the tests experience
some race conditions with RADOS Gateway deployments taking time
to resync after promotion operations that needs to be accomodated
in the zaza test code.

Related-Bug: 1833509
Change-Id: If36671a00c253e36c339e72dd14b20f7c68f7577

Fix Qinling deployment and reconfigure

The "environment" variable set in config.yml and handlers/main.yml
has been removed to fix de deployment and the reconfigure.

Hey Lingxian :-) Are you able to provide us with the templates for this demo, or links to a repo where they are available? It would make this document make more useful for operators.'}, {'account_id': 6732, 'date': '2019-06-19 21:10:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

 > make this document make more useful for operators.

The new Alarm type has been merged to Aodh just several weeks ago, it's not supported in Heat yet, there is a patch[1] for that. You can see from the demo that I created the Alarm by calling Aodh API rather than in Heat template.

After the patch merged, I will update my template and share with the community.

commit_message:
Admin image table wrong visibility for private images

This patch changes the visibility of 'Image from Other Project - Non-Public'
images to 'Private' images.Now Visibility of these images are shown as
'Private' images in admin image table.

Change-Id: I6dbb06d72597f5e14f7233199ad242700acfa042
Closes-Bug: #1624748

commit_message:
Remove the repeated calls

The create function of GlanceImageService has called
the staticmethod _translate_to_glance. So when we call
create function, we don't need to call _translate_to_glance
again. Just remove it now.

Change-Id: I26cbbec1f5d330ffa72a075b7d8321f4d6da029c

i wonder if this is still an issue since https://review.opendev.org/#/c/663710 has merged.

we are moving away from the SoftwareDeployment shim towards more native ansible tasks.

Since EnableDpdkDeployment is enabled via PreNetworkConfig, that should now always run before the network is configured with os-net-config for all roles.

It would be nice if we could migrate the host_config_and_reboot template to be a composable service that could run during deploy_step_tasks step0. Not sure if that is possible or not.'}, {'account_id': 18575, 'date': '2019-06-18 06:55:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

> we are moving away from the SoftwareDeployment shim towards more native ansible tasks. Since EnableDpdkDeployment is enabled via PreNetworkConfig, that should now always run before the network is configured with os-net-config for all roles.

That should solve the issue for Train. I will levave this issue as is for stein and rocky as it is of not priority.

> It would be nice if we could migrate the host_config_and_reboot template to be a composable service that could run during deploy_step_tasks step0. Not sure if that is possible or not.

BootParams services applies the kernel args and reboots the node at step 0. BootParams and reboot is a mandatory step for EnableDpdkDeployment. I understand that we cannot ensure the order in step 0. Do you think of any other possibilities?

As far as this patch, I will abandon it once we conclude this dicussion.'}, {'account_id': 18575, 'date': '2019-06-18 06:56:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

May be it can be moved to host_prep_tasks which will be executed after step0? I will give a try if that is a possible approach.'}, {'account_id': 18575, 'date': '2019-06-20 09:00:47.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

[{'created': '2019-06-13 04:23:09.000000000', 'message': "Use 'free' strategy for pre deployments with OvS-DPDK

With linear stragey, the order of the pre deployment resources
are mixed, which results in NetworkDeployment before DPDK is enabled.
It will result in error in openvswitch as 'dpdk' type will not be
found until DPDK is enabled in openvswitch. It throws unwanted
error logs. As per the pre config download deployemts, ensure
DPDK is enabled before NetworkDeployment. Providing 'free' strategy
for the playbooks, acheives the required behavior. It will be
applied to pre deployment step when DPDK is enabled.
Closes-Bug: #1807959

Change-Id: I2e599d3f14af8b5d7fcfbc99d6ee6588bc844987
"}, {'created': '2019-06-13 04:42:34.000000000', 'message': "Use 'free' strategy for pre deployments with OvS-DPDK

commit_message:
Use 'free' strategy for pre deployments with OvS-DPDK

With linear stragey, the order of the pre deployment resources
are mixed, which results in NetworkDeployment before DPDK is enabled.
It will result in error in openvswitch as 'dpdk' type will not be
found until DPDK is enabled in openvswitch. It throws unwanted
error logs. As like heat deployments, ensure the config download
deployemts follow the oder for pre deployment resources, to enable
DPDK before NetworkDeployment. Providing 'free' strategy for the
playbooks, acheives the required behavior. It will be applied to
pre deployment step when DPDK is enabled.
Closes-Bug: #1807959

Change-Id: I2e599d3f14af8b5d7fcfbc99d6ee6588bc844987
